title: Func def. by int.: 3 line segments

content.question: The graph of the function f above consists of three line segments. (a) Let g be the function given by <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>g</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mn>4</mn> </mrow> <mi>x</mi> </msubsup> <mi>f</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mi>d</mi> <mi>t</mi> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4551@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. For each of g(-1), g'(-1), and g''(-1), find the value or state that it does not exist.

frqParts.text: The graph of the function f above consists of three line segments. (a) Let g be the function given by <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>g</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mrow> <mo>−</mo> <mn>4</mn> </mrow> <mi>x</mi> </msubsup> <mi>f</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mi>d</mi> <mi>t</mi> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4551@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. For each of g(-1), g'(-1), and g''(-1), find the value or state that it does not exist.
(b) For the function g defined in part (a), find the x-coordinate of each point of inflection of the graph of g on the open interval -4 < x < 3. Explain your reasoning.

(c) Let h be the function given by <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mi>h</mi> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mo>=</mo> <mstyle displaystyle="true"> <mrow> <msubsup> <mo>∫</mo> <mi>x</mi> <mn>3</mn> </msubsup> <mi>f</mi> </mrow> </mstyle> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mi>t</mi> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> <mi>d</mi> <mi>t</mi> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4464@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. Find all values of x in the closed interval −4 ≤ x ≤ 3 for which h(x) = 0.
(d) For the function h defined in part (c), find all intervals on which h is decreasing. Explain your reasoning.

topic.text: 5.3: Determining Intervals on Which a Function Is Increasing or Decreasing

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
